Yes and is, in fact, how metastasis occurs. The primary tumor is where the cancer started (lung, breast, prostate, etc.). As the tumor grows, some cells will slough off and enter the blood and can be detected as circulating tumor cells (CTCs) or circulating stem cells (CSCs). Many of these will not survive but some will ‘put down roots’ so to speak and a new tumor (metastasis) will start. These days, primary tumors are not so bad and can be treated with reasonable success though there are exceptions. It is when Metastasis has occurred that the trouble begins as there are often multiple metastasis sites. These days it is not the primary tumor in cancer that kills you, it is metastasis.

No, Cancer is not contagious through blood. Even, a personal connection with a cancer patient like sharing meals cannot cause other people to have cancer. Cancer spread only within the individual disseminate from its original site and spread to other organs through blood and lymph vessels. Cancer or malignant tumor is a disease in which the formation of uncontrollably dividing cells occurs in the body. These cells capable of growing into nearby organs and tissues, as well as metastasizing to distantly located organs penetrating the blood- and lymphatic streams. The process can take years, and even decades. Malignant cells have a high growth rate, and metastases arise if these cells germinate into the vessels. After this, the process of dissemination of cancer cells throughout the body cannot be stopped\controlled without such aggressive treatment like chemotherapy.

Yes. Sarcomas typically spread through the bloodstream, as does Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma. Epithelial cancers (Carcinomas) typically spread through lymph channels, that’s why they can sometimes be found in lymph nodes. These are just rules of the thumb. Exceptions abound. Each cancer is different, even those with the same names and origins. That’s why they are so difficult to treat.
